explanation:
Why each symbol is required for analyzing invariant controlling expressions (MISRA C):

- struct MHD_Connection::daemon and daemon->client_discipline
  - discp_lvl is derived from this field; many boolean controlling expressions (skip_empty_lines, skip_several_empty_lines, skip_unlimited_empty_lines, tab_as_wsp, other_wsp_as_wsp, wsp_blocks, wsp_in_uri, wsp_in_uri_keep, bare_cr_keep, bare_cr_as_sp) are computed directly from client_discipline. You must know whether client_discipline is mutable during the call and how its value is defined to judge if those controlling expressions are invariant.

- MHD_ALLOW_BARE_LF_AS_CRLF_
  - Macro/function used to compute bare_lf_as_crlf; its expansion/definition determines whether that boolean is invariant and how it depends on discp_lvl (or other state).

- struct MHD_Connection::read_buffer_offset, read_buffer_size, read_buffer, state
  - These fields appear in loop/if controlling expressions (e.g. if (0 == read_buffer_offset), while (p < read_buffer_offset), checks of read_buffer[0], read_buffer_offset comparisons). They are also modified throughout the function. You need their definitions and semantics to decide whether the controlling expressions can change (i.e. are not invariant) as the function executes.

- MHD_CONNECTION_INIT, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING
  - State constants used in assertions and assignments; needed to know possible values of c->state and whether comparisons against them are invariant.

- struct MHD_Request and its members referenced (rq.method, rq.url, rq.url_len, rq.version, rq.http_mthd, req_target_len, num_cr_sp_replaced)
  - These fields are tested/updated and appear in conditions (method presence, version presence, http_mthd range checks). Their mutability and initial values affect whether conditionals are invariant.

- rq.hdrs.rq_line.* members (proc_pos, skipped_empty_lines, last_ws_start, last_ws_end, rq_tgt, num_ws_in_uri, rq_tgt_qmark)
  - These are read and written and are central to the loop and many if conditions (e.g. p == proc_pos, last_ws_* checks, skipped_empty_lines bounds). You must know their types and how they change to determine if the controlling expressions are invariant.

- MHD_HTTP_MTHD_NO_METHOD, MHD_HTTP_MTHD_GET, MHD_HTTP_MTHD_DELETE
  - Constants used in method-related range tests that control error-path selection. Their numeric ordering/values are required to know if comparisons can be invariant.

- MHD_MAX_EMPTY_LINES_SKIP, HTTP_VER_LEN
  - Numeric constants used in conditions that detect protocol errors; needed to reason whether those comparisons are invariant given runtime-modified operands.

- connection_close_error, transmit_error_response_static, transmit_error_response_len, parse_http_version, parse_http_std_method
  - Called functions can have side effects on c (for example change c->state, close the connection, modify buffer offsets, or longjmp/exit-like behavior). Knowing whether these calls modify the variables used in subsequent controlling expressions is essential to conclude whether those expressions remain invariant across execution paths.

- BARE_CR_IN_HEADER, BARE_LF_IN_HEADER, REQUEST_MALFORMED, RQ_LINE_TOO_MANY_WSP
  - Error identifiers passed to transmit functions; needed to understand which error branches are taken and whether a controlling expression leads to an early exit (thus not forming an invariant loop/condition in the remainder of the function).

- mhd_assert
  - Assertions in the code document intended invariants; their semantics (compile-time vs runtime, side effects) help decide whether a controlling expression is deliberately invariant or an intended defensive check.

- _ (gettext)
  - Used in error messages passed to connection_close_error; inclusion is for completeness to understand side-effecting calls (mostly not altering invariants, but needed to reason about full callees).

In short: to decide whether any controlling expression is an impermissible invariant you must know (a) how the boolean expressions are computed (client_discipline and MHD_ALLOW_BARE_LF_AS_CRLF_), (b) which operands in conditions can be mutated inside this function or by its callees (all c->* and rq.* fields listed), and (c) whether the called functions can change those operands or cause early exits. The symbols above are the minimal set needed to make that determination.
